content: SEC. 101. Extension of the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families Block Grant Program through March 31, 2004. Activities authorized by part A of title IV of the Social Security Act, and by sections 510, 1108(b), and 1925, shall continue through March 31, 2004, with necessary appropriations. Grants and payments can be made for these activities in the first two quarters of fiscal year 2004 at the level provided for in 2002. Amendments are made for supplemental grants in certain states. Amendments are made to various sections of the Social Security Act, including changing the fiscal year from 2001 to fiscal year 2001, adjusting the contingency fund from 2003 to 2004, and modifying the maintenance of effort requirements for 2004 and 2005. SEC. 102 extends the National Random Sample Study of Child Welfare and Child Welfare Waiver Authority through March 31, 2004, with necessary appropriations. SEC. 201 amends the Internal Revenue Code to disclose return information for income contingent repayment of student loans until December 31, 2004. SEC. 202 extends Internal Revenue Service user fees under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Secretary will establish a program for user fees for requests to the IRS for ruling letters, opinion letters, and determination letters. Fees will vary based on categories, be determined by request complexity, and must be paid in advance. Exemptions and reduced fees will be provided as deemed appropriate, with an exemption for certain pension plan determination letter requests. The IRS will establish a program for user fees for ruling letters, opinion letters, and determination letters related to pension benefit plans maintained by eligible employers or trusts. The IRS will establish a program for user fees for ruling letters, opinion letters, and determination letters related to pension benefit plans maintained by eligible employers or trusts. Additionally, the pension benefit plan must meet certain requirements by the end of the fifth plan year or within the first 5 plan years. The IRS will establish a program for user fees for ruling letters, opinion letters, and determination letters related to pension benefit plans maintained by eligible employers or trusts. The sponsor of any prototype plan intended for marketing to participating employers must comply with certain definitions and rules, including the determination of average fees charged. The IRS will establish a program for user fees for ruling letters, opinion letters, and determination letters related to pension benefit plans. The average fee charged under the program shall not be less than the amount determined in a specified table. The IRS will establish a program for user fees for ruling letters, opinion letters, and determination letters related to pension benefit plans. The fees range from $200 to $350 for various types of rulings and determinations. No fee shall be imposed for requests made after December 31, 2004. The Revenue Act of 1987 and the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 are repealed. Fees collected under the Internal Revenue Code must be approved by an appropriations Act. Amendments apply to requests made after the enactment date. COBRA fees are extended to March 31, 2004. Medicare cost-sharing is extended for certain qualifying individuals. The Social Security Act is amended to extend Medicare cost-sharing for qualifying individuals until March 2004 and allocate funds for fiscal years 2002 and 2003. Additionally, a special rule is established for the first quarter of 2004. The Social Security Act is amended to extend Medicare cost-sharing for qualifying individuals until March 2004 and allocate funds for fiscal years 2002 and 2003. A special rule is established for the first quarter of 2004, with a total allocation amount of $100,000,000. SEC. 402 extends the provision equalizing urban and rural standardized Medicare inpatient hospital payments. The provision equalizing urban and rural standardized Medicare inpatient hospital payments is extended until March 31, 2004. The Secretary of Health and Human Services has the authority to delay implementation if necessary, but not later than November 1, 2003. The Secretary has the authority to delay implementation of amendments to ensure total payments for inpatient hospital services remain the same for fiscal year 2004. The application of the amendments will not affect payment rates after September 30, 2004. The Secretary is not required to conduct rulemaking or notice for administration of these provisions. The Secretary has the authority to delay implementation of amendments to maintain payment rates for inpatient hospital services in fiscal year 2004. There is no administrative or judicial review of any delays or determinations made by the Secretary regarding payment rates.
